sentence: Home improvement warehouse operator The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) saw its earnings estimates and price target lowered on Tuesday by analysts at FBR Capital Markets.
The firm, which reiterated its "Outperform" rating for the stock, cut its target to $36 from $40.
That new target represents a 12% upside from HD's Monday closing price of $32.06.

An FBR analyst commented, "The Street has become accustomed to 'EPS beats,' with HD seeing nine of its last nine quarters ahead of consensus… We expect things to resume their course here in 2H10E, when others within retail face relatively tougher YOY sales comparisons against what turned out to be decent holidays a year ago (Black Friday, for example)… HD guidance calls for Q210E to be lower than Q110A, when total company same-store sales were up 4.8% and comps at U.S. stores rose 3.3%… We point out that (The Home Depot) is in the process of sustaining positive comparable store sales for the first time since 2H05/1H06… So, we expect that the share price will be able to garner higher premium valuations to the overall market, for the time being."
Accordingly, the firm cut its 2010 full-year EPS estimate from $1.95 to $1.89, and its 2011 estimate from $2.30 to $2.27.
Home Depot shares were mostly flat in premarket trading Tuesday.
We recently removed shares of HD from our recommended list, back on May 25, when the stock was trading at $33.22.
The company has a 2.93% dividend yield, based on last night's closing stock price of $32.06.
The stock has technical support in the $28-$29 price area.
If the shares can firm up, we see overhead resistance around the $34-$36 price levels.
We would remain on the sidelines for now.
The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) is not recommended at this time, holding a Dividend.com DARS™ Rating of 3.4 out of 5 stars.
